conclusion: Analyze forces acting on the system when the object is at rest.
Object is suspended at point D by a non-extendable light rope, rings E and F can move freely along rods OA and OB.
Angle between OA and OB is 45°, OA is vertical.
Weight of the object (mg) acts vertically downward at point D.
Tension in the rope acts upward at point D.
Forces between the rings and the rods are F1 (between ring E and rod OA) and F2 (between ring F and rod OB).
Since the object is at rest, the system is in equilibrium, so the sum of forces in both horizontal and vertical directions must be zero.
Vertical component of the tension in the rope must balance the weight of the object.
Tension in the rope can be decomposed into two components: one along OA and one along OB.
Horizontal components of the forces F1 and F2 must balance each other since there is no horizontal movement.
Let T be the tension in the rope. The tension has components along OA and OB.
Angle between OA and OB is 45°, so components of the tension along OA and OB will be equal due to symmetry.
Since OA is vertical, component of the tension along OA is T cos(45°).
Since OB is at a 45° angle to the vertical, component of the tension along OB is also T cos(45°).
Vertical component of the tension must equal the weight of the object: T sin(45°) = mg.
Solving for T gives: T = mg / sin(45°) = mg / (√2/2) = mg√2.
F1 is the force between ring E and rod OA, which is the vertical component of the tension: F1 = T cos(45°) = mg√2 * (√2/2) = mg.
F2 is the force between ring F and rod OB, which is the horizontal component of the tension: F2 = T cos(45°) = mg√2 * (√2/2) = mg.
Final Answer: F1 = mg, F2 = mg.
